facts.text: Ravi Datt Joshi was the Assistant District Inspector of Schools at Kamal in 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961 Ravi Datt Joshi was the Assistant District Inspector of Schools at Kamal and the appellant was then working under, him as a clerk.

facts.text: The appellant was working as a clerk under Joshi in 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961 Ravi Datt Joshi was the Assistant District Inspector of Schools at Kamal and the appellant was then working under, him as a clerk.

facts.text: Between March and December 1961, Joshi authorised the appellant to draw certain amounts from the State Bank of India, Karnal.

anchor.surface_text: Between March to December 1961, Joshi authorised the appellant to draw certain amounts from the State Bank of India, Karnal.

facts.text: On March 11, 1961, the appellant drew Rs. 979.12 for payment to M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on March 11, 1961, the appellant drew Rs. 979.12 for payment to M s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons.

facts.text: The Rs. 979.12 drawn on March 11, 1961 was not paid to M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on March 11, 1961, the appellant drew Rs. 979.12 for payment to M s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons. On March 31, 1961, he drew a further sum of Rs. 1449.38 out of which Rs. 1404 were to be paid to the Indian Red Cross Society. He made an entry in the cash book showing as if that amount was paid to the said Society and got that entry initialled by Joshi.

facts.text: On March 31, 1961, appellant drew Rs. 1449.38, of which Rs. 1404 were to be paid to Indian Red Cross Society.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1961, he drew a further sum of Rs. 1449.38 out of which Rs. 1404 were to be paid to the Indian Red Cross Society.

facts.text: Appellant made an entry in cash book showing Rs. 1404 paid to Indian Red Cross Society and got it initialled by Joshi.

anchor.surface_text: He made an entry in the cash book showing as if that amount was paid to the said Society and got that entry initialled by Joshi.

facts.text: The amount for Indian Red Cross Society was not paid.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1961, he drew a further sum of Rs. 1449.38 out of which Rs. 1404 were to be paid to the Indian Red Cross Society. He made an entry in the cash book showing as if that amount was paid to the said Society and got that entry initialled by Joshi.

facts.text: On July 3, 1961, appellant encashed bill for Rs. 424 payable to teachers Ishwar Datt and Chand Ram.

anchor.surface_text: On July 3, 1961, he encashed a bill for Rs. 424, the amount being payable to two teachers, Ishwar Datt and Chand Ram.

facts.text: Appellant made entry in acquittance roll showing Rs. 200 paid to Chand Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an entry in the acquittance roll showing as if he had paid Rs. 200 to Chand Ram.

facts.text: On November 15, 1961, appellant received Rs. 281.15 in respect of arrears of salary of teacher Harbhajan Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: On November 15, 1961 he received Rs. 281.15 in respect of arrears of salary of one teacher, Harbhajan Kaur

facts.text: On December 2, 1961, appellant received Rs. 42.66 salary of teacher Ram Sarup and Rs. 494 contingent fund payable to staff.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 2, 1961, he received Rs. 42.66 and Rs. 494, the first amount being the, salary of Ram Sarup, another teacher and the other as companytingent fund payable to the staff.

facts.text: None of the amounts received by appellant were paid to the intended recipients.

anchor.surface_text: None of these amounts was paid to any of the aforesaid persons for payment to whom they were received by him.

facts.text: M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons complained to Joshi that amount due was not paid.

anchor.surface_text: On M s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons companyplaining to Joshi that the amount due to them was number paid, Joshi looked into the matter

facts.text: Joshi lodged a complaint before the Police after finding amounts embezzled.

anchor.surface_text: and finding that that amount and other amounts were embezzled, he lodged a companyplaint before the Police.

facts.text: Police registered case under s. 409 against appellant and under ss. 409, 465, 477-A, 120-B against Joshi.

anchor.surface_text: The police thereupon registered a case under s. 409 against the appellant and under ss. 409, 465, 477-A and s. 120-B of the Penal Code against Joshi.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate convicted Joshi and appellant under s. 120-B, s. 409 for Rs. 3414.53, and s. 477-A with sentences and fines concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate companyvicted Joshi and the appellant under s. 120-B and under s. 409 for criminal breach of trust in respect of Rs. 3414.53 and also under s. 477-A and awarded different sentences and fines directing the sentences to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted Joshi of all charges, acquitted appellant of s.120-B and s.477-A, upheld conviction under s.409.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Additional Sessions Judge acquitted Joshi of all the charges. He also acquitted the appellant on charges under s. 120-B and s. 477-A but upheld his companyviction under s. 409.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision in Punjab High Court, Criminal Revision No. 824 of 1963.

facts.text: High Court judgment and order dated December 20, 1963 dismissing revision.

facts.text: In High Court, appellant conceded he received the amounts but claimed handed to Joshi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1963 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 824 of 1963.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in proceeding with the case as if the appellant had to prove his case beyond reasonable doubt that he had handed over the said moneys to Joshi?

holdings.text: The High Court did not err in holding the appellant guilty under s.409 as no reasonable doubt was raised regarding misappropriation due to his admissions, extra-judicial confession, and false representations.

anchor.surface_text: There was, however, no question of the appellant raising any reasonable doubt in view of a his admission that he had received the said moneys, b the evidence of the District Inspector of Schools that he had confessed before him of having misappro- priated Rs. 2500 at least

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's admission of receipt, confession of misappropriating Rs.2500, and false representations to payees preclude raising reasonable doubt on prosecution case.

holdings.text: The appellant was not prejudiced by non-production of documents as they were either produced, irrelevant, or untraceable, and his confession overrides any potential doubt.

anchor.surface_text: We find, therefore, no substance in the contention that if these documents had been produced the appellant could have, thrown some doubt on the prosecution evidence and could have made out a reasonably probable case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents addressed in trial report; no objection raised timely; confession and non-remittance negate relevance; no prejudice shown.

holdings.text: Moneys were entrusted to the appellant in his capacity as a public servant clerk under s.409 IPC as he was authorised to draw and receive for express purpose of payment.

anchor.surface_text: There was, therefore, entrustment to the appellant of the said moneys for an express purpose. The decision in Budha Lals case cannot apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant routinely handled moneys; specific authorisation for payment constitutes entrustment in official capacity; distinguishes Budha Lal on facts.

holdings.text: Conviction under s.409 IPC is valid even if charge was under s.409 r/w s.120B and conspiracy not proved, as substantive offence can be independently established.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there is no substance in this contention. If the charge of conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust is followed by a substantive charge of criminal breach of trust

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court may convict on substantive charge despite conspiracy failure; no prejudice; follows Willie Slaney, contra Kerala case.

holdings.text: No misjoinder of charges vitiated the trial as no timely objection raised and no prejudice shown.

anchor.surface_text: He has also not shown that any prejudice was caused to him and that being so this contention also must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant failed to object earlier or demonstrate embarrassment in defence.

holdings.text: Absence of sanction under s.196A(2) CrPC for s.120B and s.477A charges does not vitiate trial or conviction on substantive s.409 charge.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sanction required only for conspiracy; substantive offence triable independently; no prejudice due to confession; follows precedents like Sukumar Chatterjee.

precedents.case_name: Woolmington v Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: if the appellant could show that his case was reasonably probable and could cast a doubt on the prosecution case that would be enough to entitle him to the benefit of reasonable doubt

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Mian v. The King 3

precedents.cited_proposition: sanction to prosecute is a condition precedent to the institution of prosecution and that it is the sanction which confers jurisdiction on the court to try the case

anchor.surface_text: Govindram Sunder Das v. Emperor 4

precedents.cited_proposition: where the offence of conspiracy to commit forgery is charged against a person and the previous consent of the local Government under s. 196A though required is not obtained, the court cannot take cognizance of the complaint

anchor.surface_text: Sukumar Chatterjee v. Mosizuddin Ahmed 1

precedents.cited_proposition: where the charge was under S. 404 read with S. 120- B and no sanction was obtained it was held that the case could proceed though only under S. 404

precedents.citation: Syed Yawar Bakht v. The Emperor 2

anchor.surface_text: Syed Yawar Bakht v. The Emperor 2

precedents.cited_proposition: the accused was charged under s. 120-B read with s. 467 and also under s. 467 read with S. 109 of the Penal Code. No sanction was obtained. It was held that the consequence of not obtaining the sanction was as if the charge under s. 120B read with S. 467 had never been framed but the accused could be convicted under the other charge

anchor.surface_text: Ram Pat v. State 3

precedents.cited_proposition: where a complaint discloses more offences than one, some of which can be inquired into without sanction and others only after sanction has been obtained, there can be no objection to the inquiry being carried on in respect of the first category of offences

anchor.surface_text: Nibaran Chandra Bhattacharyya v. Emperor 4

precedents.cited_proposition: the learned Judge accepted the contention that the trial was vitiated as no sanction was obtained in respect of the charge under S. 120-B and set aside the conviction also under S. 384 and S. 384 read with S. 114 passed against petitioners 1 and 2 because prejudice was caused

precedents.citation: Mohd. Bachal Abdulla v. The Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Mohd. Bachal Abdulla v. The Emperor 1

precedents.cited_proposition: The absence of sanction does not prevent the court from proceeding with the trial if the complaint also charges a conspirator of the principal offence committed in pursuance of the conspiracy or for abetment by him of any such offence committed by one of the conspirators under s. 109 of the Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the fact that sanction was not obtained in respect of the complaint under s. 120-B did not vitiate the trial on the substantive charge under s. 409.

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions raised by the appellant rejected; conviction of the appellant under Section 409 IPC for criminal breach of trust upheld; trial not vitiated due to lack of sanction for conspiracy charge
